The reason your mother liquor went black is because you've got hot spots in the boiling setup.  I use a flat-bottom 1l single neck, and with sulfuric as high as 1.125 : 1, mass ratio, I have no darkening at all, with the flask suspended in an oil bath.  Also, try using the oil temperature as your reference; the high LHv of the ether will carry away enough heat to keep the mixture at a decent thermal equilibrium with minimal effort.  Peace.

How about using acidic molecular sieves or magnesium sulfate in the first step (mixture of ethanol and sulfuric acid) and a reflux condenser connected to a water bath with about 40°C? The sieves/magnesium sulfate would pull out water that is produced during the synthesis and therefore increase the yield and the reflux condenser would keep the sulfuric acid and ethanol in the first flask so the yield would be increased too. Would this work?

P. S.: Ethanol and Sulfuric acid react to Diethyl sulfate, which is an extremely toxic ethylating agent, so keep that in mind.
